cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

courses.name: Stem Cell Biology: Developmental Models and Cell-based Therapeutics

cmCourseInfo.description: Stem cells provide the basis for cellular diversity in multicellular organisms and have enormous therapeutic potential in regenerative medicine. The course will introduce students to the differences and similarities between stem cells from different organisms, their roles throughout development and therapeutic potential.
cmCourseInfo.title: Stem Cell Biology: Developmental Models and Cell-based Therapeutics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

No special hardware or software is required. A laptop/PC/mobile with internet connection is sufficient.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how the central and peripheral nervous system controls breathing in mammals. Topics include how the brain generates rhythmic breathing movements, how sleep impacts breathing control and how abnormal breathing contributes to disorders such as sleep apnea.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurobiology of Respiration

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week. Students will have the opportunity for online class 1-2hrs/week (Monday and Wednesday 6-7pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra)

cmCourseInfo.description: Use of available programs for analyzing biological data. This is an introductory course with a strong emphasis on hands-on methods. Some theory is introduced, but the main focus is on using extant bioinformatics tools to analyze data and generate biological hypotheses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Bioinformatic Methods

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In-class activities, including pre-lab talk and practicals of the course, will be available only as online synchronous via Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) with no recording. Students must have the ability to access and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra), Quercus and Coursera. Students must be able to attend classes live via Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) and write quizzes on Quercus during scheduled times (Eastern Standard Time) with stable internet connections. It is strongly recommended to have multiple different routes/sources of lined high speed broadband internet connection in order to prevent disconnections. Please note that we do not manually add non-registered students (including students on the waiting list) to any course platforms (including but not limited to Quercus, Bb Collaborate (Ultra) and any guest access). The course instructor will provide details.

courses.name: Research Abroad in Cell & Systems Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: An independent research project conducted in molecular biology, cell biology, developmental biology, neurobiology, physiology or systems biology. Whole organism, cell culture, in vitro or in silico studies are acceptable. The laboratory research is conducted by the student and supervised by a faculty member at an approved partner university. An information session is held each fall, and an application and interview process is required. The research is typically conducted from May to August. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Abroad in Cell & Systems Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum grade of 73% in BIO230H1/BIO255H1/BIO271H1 and permission of the CSB397Y0 coordinator

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

To enrol in this course, please contact the CSB Undergraduate Administrator.

Delivery Instructions

The delivery of these independent research projects will be done remotely in summer 2021.  There will be online synchronous and online asynchronous components.  Additional details will be provided by the supervisor at the host institution.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

courses.name: Independent Research in Cell and Systems Biology I

cmCourseInfo.description: An original research project (a literature review alone is not sufficient) requiring the prior consent of a member of the Department to supervise the project. The topic is to be mutually agreed upon by the student and supervisor. They must arrange the time, place, and provision of any materials and submit to the Undergraduate Office a signed form of agreement outlining details prior to being enrolled. In the Fall or Winter sessions, a commitment of 8-10 hours per week is expected for research and related course activities. If spread over both the Fall and Winter sessions, a commitment of 4-5 hours per week is expected. In the Summer Session, the number of hours doubles per week (e.g., 16-20 for F or S, or 8-10 for Y) as the length of the term is halved compared to the Fall or Winter term. Many students spend more than this amount of time as they become immersed in their project. This course is normally open only to fourth year students with adequate background in Cell and Systems Biology. Course requirements include a final report, and either an oral presentation (Summer and Fall sessions) or a poster presentation (Winter session). Two workshops on scientific research are scheduled and highly recommended. Details for enrollment are available at the Undergraduate course section of the CSB website, http://csb.utoronto.ca. Maximum of 2.0 FCEs allowed among CSB497H1, CSB498Y1 and CSB499Y1. (Lab Materials Fee: $25). Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research in Cell and Systems Biology I

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must submit a completed CSB497/498/499 contract to the CSB Undergraduate Office at janet.mannone@utoronto.ca by Friday, 30 April 2021, before being enrolled. Contracts are available on our website at https://csb.utoronto.ca/undergraduate-studies/forms/. For more information please contact janet.mannone@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project.  The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student.  Students are responsible for contacting possible supervisors.  The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components).  In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.

courses.name: Independent Research in Cell and Systems Biology II

cmCourseInfo.description: Allows students to do a second independent project. Operates in the same manner as CSB497H1/CSB498Y1. Maximum of 2.0 FCEs allowed among CSB497H1, CSB498Y1 and CSB499Y1. Students who have completed both CSB497H1 and CSB498Y1 are excluded from taking CSB499Y1. (Lab Materials Fee: $50). Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
